title: Learn Dutch with Motivational Stories – Improve Your Dutch Listening Skills
content: Hello everyone, Welcome to our channel where learning Dutch becomes an exciting adventure. Today, you don't just watch a video. You step into a new reality. Listen carefully. This moment could change your life forever. I'm here to tell you something that no one else will tell you. Something that can ignite a fire in your soul. May I ask you something? Are you happy with your life right now? If you died tomorrow, would you be proud of what you have achieved so far? If the answer is no, then this is your wake up call. Let me tell you something. Your life doesn't change overnight. It doesn't get better by luck. The life you desire will only become a reality if you decide to change it. Stop living between excuses. You've been making them up for far too long. I'm too young, I'm too old. I have no money. I don't have enough time. They are lies. Excuses are lies you tell yourself to avoid responsibility. Do you know why most people fail not because of bad luck, not because of a lack of intelligence. They fail because they do nothing. They sit still and complain about their problems instead of solving them. Do you think successful people had it easy? I'll give you a clear example. Oprah Winfrey was born into poverty and went through difficult things. People said she would never make it, but she didn't listen to others. She worked hard and stayed focused. Today, she is one of the most influential people in the world. What's holding you back? Nothing, except your own way of thinking. Imagine what your life could look like. Close your eyes for a moment and imagine this. You wake up in a beautiful house. The house of your dreams. Outside, there is a luxury car in your driveway. Your parents smile, knowing that they don't have to worry about anything anymore. You took care of them. You gave them the life they deserve. The life they dreamed of for you. That life they envisioned while working hard every day. Open your eyes again. Does it sound impossible? It is not. This life is absolutely possible. But it takes one thing: your dedication to change. Your habits shape your future. I want to be honest with you. Your habits build you up. Or break you down. There is no middle ground. If you spend hours watching Netflix, sitting on Instagram, or playing video games, you're throwing away your future. Time is the most valuable thing you have. Every second you waste, you don't get back. What distinguishes successful people from others? They use their time wisely. They read books, learn new things and work on their dreams. They don't waste their time. Think of your parents. Your mother carried you for nine months. She gave up her dreams, her health and her rest. Just to give you life. Your father worked day and night to give you food, education, and opportunities. Now it's your turn. What do you do to give them back what they have done for you? Don't want to see them happy? Don't you want to give them the life they always dreamed of? Imagine your mother's face when you give her the key to her dream house? Imagine the tears in your father's eyes when you tell him that he will never have to work again because you made it. It's not just about money. It's about giving them peace, joy, and pride. Proud to be able to say my child made it. Success requires sacrifices. I'm going to tell you something you might not want to hear. Success is not easy. It means getting up early, even if you want to stay in bed. Work on your goals while your friends go out. Saying no to distractions. There is a story about a young man who wanted to be successful. He went to a wise man and asked: How do I achieve success? The sage took him to the sea. They walked into the water together. The sage pushed his head underwater. The boy struggled. He had to breathe. When he came up, gasping for breath, the sage said. If you want success, as your breath needed, then you will achieve it. Ask yourself: how badly do you really want it? Surround yourself with winners. Look at your friends. Lift them you on Or are they pulling you down? If your friends are negative, lazy, or unmotivated, you know what's happening. Then you will become just like them. Success isn't just about hard work. It's also about the environment you choose. Surround yourself with people who inspire, challenge, and make you better. If that means ending friendships that are harming you, do it. Your future is more important than their opinion. Believe in yourself. This is the most important thing I can tell you today. You have to believe in yourself. No one else is going to do that for you. The world is full of critics. They will say you are not good enough, you are not smart enough, you can't do it. Proves the opposite. Believe in your potential. Believe that you can achieve anything. And what about failure? Failure is not the end. It is the beginning. Every successful person has failed more often than you think. Michael Jordan was rejected for the school team. He gave up. No, he trained harder, worked more and became a legend. Failure is a lesson. It is a step on the way. Accept it, learn from it and move on. Take time for yourself. The world is loud. Social media, appointments, responsibilities, everything requires your attention. But when was the last time you really thought about yourself? What is really important to you? Take a few minutes every day just for yourself. Meditate, think, or breathe deeply. It is not a waste of time. It is essential for your mind. If you don't take yourself seriously, who will? And yes, talk to yourself. Say things like I'm strong, I'm valuable, I can achieve great things. Train your mind. Your brain is like a garden. What your plant grows. If you sow doubt, fear and negativity, that's what you get. Plant courage, hope, and confidence and you will flourish. Say it out loud: I'm the best. Nothing can stop me. I can achieve what I want. Write it down and repeat it every day. Even though it feels weird. It works. Your mind believes what it often hears. Stop feeding yourself with. I can't do it and start with I can do this, I'm going to do this. I'm ready. Visualize your dream life. Close your eyes and see it in front of you. Your dream job, the salary you want. Your own home. The love of your life. Traveling around the world. Feel it. Feel the happiness that that would give you. Now open your eyes and understand. Every major change starts in your mind. If you can think of it, you can achieve it. But just thinking is not enough. You have to act, control your mind and you control your life. Your mind is a powerful tool. If you don't control it, it will control you. Be aware of that. Think about it. How often do you have negative thoughts? Sentences like I'm not good enough, I'm going to fail. This is not for me, unconsciously holding you back. When those thoughts come, say out loud. Stopper! I choose what I think. Choose positive thoughts. Your mind is like a muscle. The more you train, the stronger it gets. Train your mind to see solutions. No problems. Train him to see opportunities. No obstacles. You are stronger than you think. Everything you need is already inside you. What is missing? Believe in yourself. Do you want a good job? You can get it. Do you want to marry the love of your life? Of course you can. Travel Building, Owning a house, Seeing the world. Making dreams come true. Yes, you can do it. The only one holding you back is you. So step aside and start moving towards your goals. Believe that your success, luck and deserves all the beauty in life. Start small. Dream big. Big dreams can seem overwhelming, but take one step at a time. Do you want to get fit? Start with 10 minutes of exercise a day. Do you want to improve your Dutch? Learn five new words a day. Do you want to save? Start with €10 per week. Those small steps may seem insignificant, but they make all the difference. Day after day, week after week, year after year. And suddenly you are much further than you thought. Be your own guy. Don't wait for others to motivate you. Don't wait until someone believes in you more than you do. Look in the mirror and say: I am proud of myself. I work hard, I grow, I can do this. You don't need permission to follow your dreams. Believe in yourself. Stand behind yourself and don't stop because of what others say. Surround yourself with people who inspire you. Listen to motivational speeches, read positive books, follow people who have already achieved what you want. Positive environment, Positive progress. Simple. Think of Thomas Edison. He failed more than a thousand times before he invented the light bulb. When people asked about his failures, he said I didn't fail. I discovered a thousand ways that didn't work. Every night, ask yourself: what did I do today to get closer to my goals, and what can I do better tomorrow? And then do it. Persistence is the key to true success. And while you're dreaming, don't forget to be grateful. Gratitude changes how you see the world. It reminds you how far you've come and gives you strength to keep going. Every morning, write down three things you're grateful for: your family, your health, or just this. You are alive and you have a new day. A new day is a new chance.

title: Learn Dutch with Vincent van Gogh's Story | Dutch Listening Practice B1-B2 with English Subtitles
content: Did you know that he only sold one painting during his entire lifetime? So why did he still become one of the most famous painters in the world? In this story, you'll discover the answer — along with other fascinating facts about his extraordinary life. By the way, my name is Markus and I’m an enthusiastic Dutch teacher. That’s why today, I’m reading you this special story. You can always turn on the subtitles to help you understand the story better. Oh, and before we begin — please let me know in the comments why you're learning Dutch, and what you enjoy learning the most. I’d really love to hear from you! Think of it as a little writing exercise in Dutch. If you enjoy this content, make sure to leave a like. Don’t forget to hit the bell so you don’t miss any new videos. You can look forward to daily new videos to help you improve your Dutch. Do you have suggestions, or is there something specific you’d like to learn? Let me know in the comments — I’m always open to new ideas! You can experience this story in two ways. You can sit at your laptop or on your phone, listen carefully, and write down the most important words — that will really boost your vocabulary. Or you can simply relax, read the text, or close your eyes and just listen. However you do it: this story will help you understand and feel Dutch more deeply. So stick around until the end! Vincent van Gogh was born on March 30th, 1853. He grew up in a small village in the south of the Netherlands, called Zundert. His father, Theodorus, was a minister. His mother, Anna, loved nature and drawing. Vincent was named after his stillborn brother. That baby was also named Vincent and was already buried when he was born. His parents visited that grave every year. Vincent grew up with the feeling that he was "the second one." That made him quiet, sensitive, and insecure. As a child, he didn’t enjoy playing with others. He preferred walking alone through fields and forests. That’s where he felt free and happy. He looked at the world with wide, curious eyes. He loved flowers, trees, birds, and sunlight. He began drawing at an early age. His mother noticed his talent and encouraged him. But things didn’t go well at school. He struggled with rules and often felt different from the rest. He quit his studies early. After that, he started working. He worked at an art dealership where he sold paintings. He was sent to London and later to Paris. In London, he fell in love with a girl, but she rejected him. His heart broke, and he became depressed. He returned to the Netherlands and tried various jobs. He was a teacher, bookseller, and even a lay preacher in poor villages. In Belgium, he lived among coal miners, gave away his clothes, and lived in poverty. The church thought he was too extreme. He was dismissed and felt worthless. But in that deep darkness, an idea emerged: he would become an artist. He decided to devote his life to art. He began drawing and painting. He was almost 30 years old — a late start for an artist. But he worked hard. Every single day. His brother Theo supported him financially and emotionally. They wrote long letters to each other about art, life, and feelings. Those letters still exist and are very famous. They give a beautiful insight into Vincent’s inner world. Vincent painted ordinary life: farmers, shoes, chairs, landscapes, and himself. He had no money for models, so he made many self-portraits. His style was rough, intense, and full of emotion. He painted with thick layers of paint and used bold colors. He was especially fond of yellow. To him, yellow represented light, hope, and energy. He used it often in his work. At the time, that was unusual and daring. But almost no one understood his style. His paintings didn’t sell. Critics called his work strange or even ugly. Still, he kept going. He believed in his vision. He moved to Paris and met artists like Toulouse-Lautrec, Signac, and Pissarro. There, he learned about Impressionism and bright colors. For the first time, he felt a bit understood. But the city’s chaos wore him down. In 1888, he moved to Arles, in the south of France. The light there inspired him. He painted flowers, sunflowers, and the yellow house where he lived. He felt creative, alive, full of ideas. He invited his friend Paul Gauguin to come live with him. They painted together but often argued. Vincent became jealous, nervous, and unstable. One evening, after a big fight, he cut off part of his left ear. Yes, he really did that. He wrapped it in paper and gave it to a woman in a brothel. Then he collapsed. He was taken to a mental institution. Even there, he kept painting. He looked outside from his room. He saw trees, mountains, stars, and wind. He painted The Starry Night, one of his most famous works. He worked quickly. His hands seemed unable to stop. He painted cypresses, wheat fields, rocks, and flowers. Everything around him became a painting. In 1890, he moved to the village of Auvers-sur-Oise. He was cared for by Dr. Paul Gachet. Vincent didn’t fully trust him, but kept going. In just two months, he created more than 70 paintings. But his sadness grew. He felt like a failure. On July 27th, he walked into a field with a pistol. He shot himself in the chest. Two days later, he died. He was only 37 years old. His brother Theo came to him and stayed until the end. Theo died six months later from grief. They are now buried together in Auvers. Their graves lie side by side, covered in ivy. There, they found the peace they never had in life. Only after his death did people start to appreciate his work. Johanna, Theo’s wife, kept his paintings and letters. She made sure the world got to know him. And it worked. Today, his paintings are worth millions of euros. They hang in famous museums around the world. In Amsterdam, the Van Gogh Museum is fully dedicated to him. Millions of people visit it every year. Vincent van Gogh is now one of the most famous artists ever. His style is unique and full of emotion. He painted what he felt — not just what he saw. His work still touches people today. He teaches us that it’s okay to be different. That pain and beauty can exist side by side. And that you should never give up, even if no one understands you. His life was short, but his impact is eternal. And you? You haven’t just heard his story — you’ve also practiced your Dutch. You’ve learned new words, read sentences, and felt how language can move you. Keep practicing, keep reading, keep listening. And who knows — maybe you’ll be painting with words someday too, just like Vincent, in your own unique way.

transcript.text: Did you know that he only sold one painting during his entire lifetime? So why did he still become one of the most famous painters in the world?
In this story, you'll discover the answer — along with other fascinating facts about his extraordinary life.
By the way, my name is Markus and I’m an enthusiastic Dutch teacher. That’s why today, I’m reading you this special story.

You can always turn on the subtitles to help you understand the story better. Oh, and before we begin — please let me know in the comments why you're learning Dutch, and what you enjoy learning the most.
I’d really love to hear from you! Think of it as a little writing exercise in Dutch.
If you enjoy this content, make sure to leave a like. Don’t forget to hit the bell so you don’t miss any new videos.

Do you have suggestions, or is there something specific you’d like to learn? Let me know in the comments — I’m always open to new ideas!
You can experience this story in two ways. You can sit at your laptop or on your phone, listen carefully, and write down the most important words — that will really boost your vocabulary.
Or you can simply relax, read the text, or close your eyes and just listen. However you do it: this story will help you understand and feel Dutch more deeply. So stick around until the end!

Vincent van Gogh was born on March 30th, 1853. He grew up in a small village in the south of the Netherlands, called Zundert. His father, Theodorus, was a minister. His mother, Anna, loved nature and drawing.

Vincent was named after his stillborn brother. That baby was also named Vincent and was already buried when he was born. His parents visited that grave every year. Vincent grew up with the feeling that he was "the second one."
That made him quiet, sensitive, and insecure. As a child, he didn’t enjoy playing with others. He preferred walking alone through fields and forests. That’s where he felt free and happy.
He looked at the world with wide, curious eyes. He loved flowers, trees, birds, and sunlight. He began drawing at an early age. His mother noticed his talent and encouraged him.
But things didn’t go well at school. He struggled with rules and often felt different from the rest. He quit his studies early. After that, he started working.

He worked at an art dealership where he sold paintings. He was sent to London and later to Paris. In London, he fell in love with a girl, but she rejected him. His heart broke, and he became depressed.

He returned to the Netherlands and tried various jobs. He was a teacher, bookseller, and even a lay preacher in poor villages. In Belgium, he lived among coal miners, gave away his clothes, and lived in poverty.
The church thought he was too extreme. He was dismissed and felt worthless. But in that deep darkness, an idea emerged: he would become an artist. He decided to devote his life to art.
He began drawing and painting. He was almost 30 years old — a late start for an artist. But he worked hard. Every single day.

His brother Theo supported him financially and emotionally. They wrote long letters to each other about art, life, and feelings. Those letters still exist and are very famous. They give a beautiful insight into Vincent’s inner world.

Vincent painted ordinary life: farmers, shoes, chairs, landscapes, and himself. He had no money for models, so he made many self-portraits. His style was rough, intense, and full of emotion. He painted with thick layers of paint and used bold colors.
He was especially fond of yellow. To him, yellow represented light, hope, and energy. He used it often in his work. At the time, that was unusual and daring.
But almost no one understood his style. His paintings didn’t sell. Critics called his work strange or even ugly. Still, he kept going. He believed in his vision.

He moved to Paris and met artists like Toulouse-Lautrec, Signac, and Pissarro. There, he learned about Impressionism and bright colors. For the first time, he felt a bit understood. But the city’s chaos wore him down.
In 1888, he moved to Arles, in the south of France. The light there inspired him. He painted flowers, sunflowers, and the yellow house where he lived. He felt creative, alive, full of ideas.

He invited his friend Paul Gauguin to come live with him. They painted together but often argued. Vincent became jealous, nervous, and unstable. One evening, after a big fight, he cut off part of his left ear.

Yes, he really did that. He wrapped it in paper and gave it to a woman in a brothel. Then he collapsed. He was taken to a mental institution. Even there, he kept painting. He looked outside from his room. He saw trees, mountains, stars, and wind.
He painted The Starry Night, one of his most famous works.
He worked quickly. His hands seemed unable to stop. He painted cypresses, wheat fields, rocks, and flowers. Everything around him became a painting.
In 1890, he moved to the village of Auvers-sur-Oise. He was cared for by Dr. Paul Gachet. Vincent didn’t fully trust him, but kept going. In just two months, he created more than 70 paintings.
But his sadness grew. He felt like a failure. On July 27th, he walked into a field with a pistol. He shot himself in the chest.
Two days later, he died. He was only 37 years old. His brother Theo came to him and stayed until the end. Theo died six months later from grief.
They are now buried together in Auvers. Their graves lie side by side, covered in ivy. There, they found the peace they never had in life.
Only after his death did people start to appreciate his work. Johanna, Theo’s wife, kept his paintings and letters. She made sure the world got to know him. And it worked.
Today, his paintings are worth millions of euros. They hang in famous museums around the world. In Amsterdam, the Van Gogh Museum is fully dedicated to him. Millions of people visit it every year.
Vincent van Gogh is now one of the most famous artists ever. His style is unique and full of emotion. He painted what he felt — not just what he saw. His work still touches people today.

He teaches us that it’s okay to be different. That pain and beauty can exist side by side. And that you should never give up, even if no one understands you. His life was short, but his impact is eternal.
And you? You haven’t just heard his story — you’ve also practiced your Dutch. You’ve learned new words, read sentences, and felt how language can move you.
Keep practicing, keep reading, keep listening. And who knows — maybe you’ll be painting with words someday too, just like Vincent, in your own unique way.
